ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with epileptic spasms, developmental delay, and EEG abnormalities (hypsarrhythmia) in an infant. The age (15 months) and constellation of symptoms strongly suggest this epileptic encephalopathy.
Features thin/absent corpus callosum, epileptic spasms, and developmental delay. However, typically affects females and has additional features like chorioretinal lacunae not mentioned here.
Early-onset epileptic encephalopathy with developmental delay and movement disorders (hypokinesia). Can present with various seizure types including spasms.
Early-onset seizures including spasms, severe developmental delay, and movement disorders. More common in females but can affect males.
Can cause X-linked West syndrome with thin corpus callosum, epileptic spasms, and developmental delay. Particularly relevant in male patients.
Early-onset epileptic encephalopathy with developmental delay and various seizure types. Can present with movement disorders and brain atrophy.
Early infantile epileptic encephalopathy that can evolve to West syndrome. Features severe seizures, developmental delay, and characteristic EEG pattern.
Can cause corpus callosum abnormalities, cerebral atrophy, developmental delay, and seizures. Movement disorders like hypokinesia can occur.
